lead_paragraph: SUNDAYS are still flea market days for the Fennick brothers, even after two decades in the antiques business. With their tousled Beatles haircuts and gleaming stacks of vintage luggage -- Vuitton and Goyard are specialties -- the twins and their wares make a spiffy landmark in the roiling sea of vendors at the Hell's Kitchen Flea Market, on West 39th Street between 9th and 10th Avenues.
abstract: SUNDAYS are still flea market days for the Fennick brothers, even after two decades in the antiques business. With their tousled Beatles haircuts and gleaming stacks of vintage luggage -- Vuitton and Goyard are specialties -- the twins and their wares make a spiffy landmark in the roiling sea of vendors at the Hell's Kitchen Flea Market, on West 39th Street between 9th and 10th Avenues.     The Hell's Kitchen flea, open on Saturdays and Sundays since 2003, is now the city's largest continuing open-air antiques market. On Aug. 31, its organizer, Alan Boss, closed his Chelsea Annex markets after 29 years on Sixth Avenue and 24th Street, and invited its vendors, including Rob and Ron Fennick, to head uptown.

abstract: IF the holidays have the gadget mavens in your circle shopping for $4,000 plasma televisions, $1,500 laptop computers or $350 cellphones, it may be a relief to know that there are less costly technology presents to be found as well. From literary works stored on flash drives to U.S.B.-powered cup warmers, here is a selection of interesting, clever and -- best of all -- inexpensive objects.     Baby boomers were clearly not considered when cellphones were designed. The small-screen displays often make reading text difficult except in bright lights. The Pop Up Cell Phone Magnifier, from Bart 1 Products (b1p.info), is an $8 piece of plastic that comes to the rescue, fitting over a mobile flip phone's screen to magnify the image. When the phone is closed, the plastic retracts.

snippet: To the Editor:     Jon Caramanica, when mentioning that Brady Seals of Hot Apple Pie is a cousin of Jim Seals, refers to the duo Seals and Crofts as ''70's schlock-poppers'' [''The Cover Video,'' Directions, last Sunday]. I don't see any reason to...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
abstract: To the Editor:     Jon Caramanica, when mentioning that Brady Seals of Hot Apple Pie is a cousin of Jim Seals, refers to the duo Seals and Crofts as ''70's schlock-poppers'' [''The Cover Video,'' Directions, last Sunday]. I don't see any reason to put down Jim Seals and Dash Crofts, two very creative individuals who brought us such gorgeous songs as ''Summer Breeze,'' ''Diamond Girl'' and ''Hummingbird,'' to name just a few. If this is schlock, I'd be grateful for more.    Brian Gari  Manhattan

snippet: I KNOW nothing about the epicurean proclivities of Polish heads of state. Do they prefer their pirogi boiled or fried? Do they share an enthusiasm for Tex-Mex cuisine with President Bush? Alas, I am ignorant.      But as soon as a tip came in that...
lead_paragraph: I KNOW nothing about the epicurean proclivities of Polish heads of state. Do they prefer their pirogi boiled or fried? Do they share an enthusiasm for Tex-Mex cuisine with President Bush? Alas, I am ignorant.
abstract: I KNOW nothing about the epicurean proclivities of Polish heads of state. Do they prefer their pirogi boiled or fried? Do they share an enthusiasm for Tex-Mex cuisine with President Bush? Alas, I am ignorant.      But as soon as a tip came in that a former chef to President Aleksander Kwasniewski of Poland was in the kitchen at Kredens, a three-month-old restaurant in Ridgewood, Queens, I made tracks for the M train. And if the affordable menu that the chef, Jarek Jaficki, has put together reflects what's served at state dinners in Warsaw, Mr. Kwasniewski eats well, especially when his staff sticks to Polish recipes.

snippet: Correction: David Pogue's Apr 28 column on Apple Computer's new operating system referred incorrectly to movie plot element to which he likened software feature
lead_paragraph: The David Pogue column in Business Day on April 28, about Apple Computer's new operating system, Mac OS X 10.4, referred incorrectly to a plot element in the "Superman" movies. The cosmic prison that held three villains -- an image that the column likened to the vertical panels in Apple's teleconference software -- appeared at the start of "Superman: The Movie" and again at the start of "Superman II," not at the end of "Superman II."

lead_paragraph: Raspberries in a bottle is what you get with Next raspberry juice from Serbia, a country where fruit seems to thrive. In fact, the label says there are approximately 48 crushed raspberries in the 6.7-ounce bottle. There is also a pressed apple, added to contribute a little sweetness to the sugar-free juice. And that's it. It is not made from concentrates.
abstract: Raspberries in a bottle is what you get with Next raspberry juice from Serbia, a country where fruit seems to thrive. In fact, the label says there are approximately 48 crushed raspberries in the 6.7-ounce bottle. There is also a pressed apple, added to contribute a little sweetness to the sugar-free juice. And that's it. It is not made from concentrates.     The juice is tartly delicious, a trifle thick, like a nectar; it can be diluted with water, iced tea or white wine.

snippet: Manohla Dargis comments on selections from New York Film Festival, which closes this weekend, and its sidebar program (S)
lead_paragraph: The New York Film Festival closes its 43rd year with a strong weekend selection that features films with and without distribution, and highlights from earlier festivals like Berlin and Cannes. Continuing this weekend (and beyond) is the festival's excellent sidebar program, "The Beauty of the Everyday: Japan's Shochiku Company at 110." Among this weekend's must-sees is Yasujiro Ozu's masterpiece "Late Spring" (1949), about a father (played by the great Chishu Ryu) and daughter (the equally sublime Setsuko Hara) whose harmonious life together is shattered when each decides that the other's life might be improved by marriage. One of the loveliest scenes in the film finds the father peeling an apple, paring away the skin as gently as Ozu lays bare his characters.

Now he's done another one, ''Sir Isaac's Apples,'' first seen Wednesday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater of the Juilliard School. But this one is very special for its ambition and epic scale and, finally, artistic accomplishment. Since it will almost surely never tour or be repeated, you are urged to see it before it closes Sunday afternoon.

lead_paragraph: Most of the 20 million people who regularly listen to Internet radio use a desktop, laptop or hand-held computer. SoundBridge Radio from Roku Labs (www.rokulabs.com) aims to remove the computer from the equation. This 70-watt tabletop stereo connects directly to radio stations that offer streaming talk and music.
abstract: Most of the 20 million people who regularly listen to Internet radio use a desktop, laptop or hand-held computer. SoundBridge Radio from Roku Labs (www.rokulabs.com) aims to remove the computer from the equation. This 70-watt tabletop stereo connects directly to radio stations that offer streaming talk and music.     The radio, which needs a Wi-Fi network to communicate, is expected to be out next month and to sell for $400, with a $50 discount for orders placed before Oct. 31. It comes with presets for 50 popular online stations. Listeners can browse for other stations by genre if Apple's iTunes software is running on a computer on the network, or they can manually enter station addresses through a Web browser.

lead_paragraph: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow.
abstract: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow.      SMALL steps are sometimes the better way to achieve a vision.

snippet: In horse racing parlance, there are useful horses, very nice ones and champions. By romping to an effortless nine-and-a-half-length victory over four rivals Sunday in the Grade I Go For Wand Handicap, Ashado showed that once a champion can transla...
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31 - In horse racing parlance, there are useful horses, very nice ones and champions. By romping to an effortless nine-and-a-half-length victory over four rivals Sunday in the Grade I Go For Wand Handicap, Ashado showed that once a champion can translate into always a champion.
abstract: In horse racing parlance, there are useful horses, very nice ones and champions. By romping to an effortless nine-and-a-half-length victory over four rivals Sunday in the Grade I Go For Wand Handicap, Ashado showed that once a champion can translate into always a champion.     Last year, Ashado, a daughter of Saint Ballado, won five of eight starts, including the Breeders' Cup Distaff, to be named the best 3-year-old filly in the nation. When she opened the year with lackluster performances in the Apple Blossom Handicap and the Pimlico Breeders Cup Distaff Handicap, many figured she was just a precocious filly who failed to develop and relegated to the ''very nice horse'' bin.

lead_paragraph: HARTSDALE - THE enormous Best Buy consumer electronics store on Central Avenue in Hartsdale doesn't usually offer an intimate shopping experience, but the scene in the center of the store one recent afternoon was more reminiscent of an at-home shopping party, rather than a big-box retailer.
abstract: THE enormous Best Buy consumer electronics store on Central Avenue in Hartsdale doesn't usually offer an intimate shopping experience, but the scene in the center of the store one recent afternoon was more reminiscent of an at-home shopping party, rather than a big-box retailer.      Sitting behind a counter, Jennifer Vicente, one of the store's 12 new personal shopping assistants, chatted as she rang up the sale of a Hewlett-Packard Photosmart 8250 inkjet printer to Dawn Rizzi of Dix Hills, N.Y. Ms. Rizzi, who had come to the store with three female friends, was jubilant because Ms. Vicente had helped her choose a printer in less than 30 minutes, or about half as much time as she had expected.

abstract: Stocks edged up yesterday in slow trading. Oil prices retreated from a six-week high, and companies including Wal-Mart Stores and eBay led the gains.    The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 6.06 points, or less than 0.1 percent, to 10,467.03. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 1.49 points, or 0.12 percent, to 1,197.51. The technology-focused Nasdaq composite index rose 4.33 points, or 0.21 percent, to 2,075.76. And the Russell 2000 index of smaller-capitalization stocks gained 2.64 points, or 0.43 percent, to close at 622.94.

lead_paragraph: Millions of PC users have relied on Flash drives or other pint-size hard drive storage units to safeguard valuable files. But those portable drives can be broken or lost. And if you need critical documents -- or favorite songs or photos -- while on the road, many Internet kiosk computers in places like airports do not have USB ports to plug the portable drive into.
abstract: Millions of PC users have relied on Flash drives or other pint-size hard drive storage units to safeguard valuable files. But those portable drives can be broken or lost. And if you need critical documents -- or favorite songs or photos -- while on the road, many Internet kiosk computers in places like airports do not have USB ports to plug the portable drive into.    Internet companies like Yahoo and AOL, as well as some smaller competitors, have taken aim at these problems by allowing users to store nearly any kind of file on their secure servers. The stored files can then be retrieved from any Internet-connected computer.

snippet: JAMES GEORGE SARKAR, the 27-year-old chef and owner of the sensational new restaurant called Venue, has grown all too accustomed to the Stare. Prospective customers stop at his front window and scan the menu, he told me by phone the other day, ''a...
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN - JAMES GEORGE SARKAR, the 27-year-old chef and owner of the sensational new restaurant called Venue, has grown all too accustomed to the Stare. Prospective customers stop at his front window and scan the menu, he told me by phone the other day, "and make a dumbfounded face and turn and walk away."
abstract: JAMES GEORGE SARKAR, the 27-year-old chef and owner of the sensational new restaurant called Venue, has grown all too accustomed to the Stare. Prospective customers stop at his front window and scan the menu, he told me by phone the other day, ''and make a dumbfounded face and turn and walk away.''     Their eyes would grow even wider if they ventured inside. Passing through two sets of heavy frosted-glass doors, they would find themselves in a spare but stunning two-story space, with bare blond wood floors, a dozen or so tables laid in austere blacks and whites, side walls painted shades of putty and mango, and a back wall lighted in constantly shifting neon-tinged pastels.

snippet: The 2005 growing season is leaving behind a patchwork of parched acres a few towns away from productive ones, with farmers who have access to irrigation systems suffering from increased fuel costs, farmers without water despairing about lost crops...
lead_paragraph: The 2005 growing season is leaving behind a patchwork of parched acres a few towns away from productive ones, with farmers who have access to irrigation systems suffering from increased fuel costs, farmers without water despairing about lost crops, and flighty rains soaking a field here and a field there but always leaving the land thirsty for more.
abstract: The 2005 growing season is leaving behind a patchwork of parched acres a few towns away from productive ones, with farmers who have access to irrigation systems suffering from increased fuel costs, farmers without water despairing about lost crops, and flighty rains soaking a field here and a field there but always leaving the land thirsty for more.     The New Jersey Emergency Board of the federal Department of Agriculture voted unanimously yesterday to ask Acting Governor Richard J. Codey to seek a federal disaster declaration, which would allow for emergency loans and debt restructuring for qualifying farmers.

snippet: DINERS negotiating the S turns along the Amawalk Reservoir here may feel a little like pioneers entering a wilderness. But I.B.M. and PepsiCo have campuses nearby, and the Granite Springs Inn beckons like a grange hall on a Saturday night. For any...
lead_paragraph: GRANITE SPRINGS - DINERS negotiating the S turns along the Amawalk Reservoir here may feel a little like pioneers entering a wilderness. But I.B.M. and PepsiCo have campuses nearby, and the Granite Springs Inn beckons like a grange hall on a Saturday night. For anyone seeking an honest meal and some fun on a night out, the inn, open since June, offers more than a few good reasons to come in from the cold.
abstract: DINERS negotiating the S turns along the Amawalk Reservoir here may feel a little like pioneers entering a wilderness. But I.B.M. and PepsiCo have campuses nearby, and the Granite Springs Inn beckons like a grange hall on a Saturday night. For anyone seeking an honest meal and some fun on a night out, the inn, open since June, offers more than a few good reasons to come in from the cold.      Pumpkins and chrysanthemums line the steps, and although the temporary signs are like those advertising used car lots, the interior has a fresh high-gloss rusticity. Antique farm tools and floor-length draperies dress up the big, open dining room; the handsome eat-in bar sports wooden shutters and shades of moss and teal. On consecutive Saturday nights in October, the parking lot was jammed by 7:30.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO - THE announcement by Yahoo on Tuesday that it is starting a discount online subscription music service sent competitors in the business reeling.
abstract: THE announcement by Yahoo on Tuesday that it is starting a discount online subscription music service sent competitors in the business reeling.    Shares of RealNetworks plunged 21 percent yesterday to close at $5.76, while Napster fell nearly 27 percent to close at $4.65. Apple Computer, whose iTunes music service has a 70 percent share of the online music market, declined 2 percent, closing at $35.61.

lead_paragraph: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow.
abstract: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow.      WE suffer an unemployment rate of nearly 30 percent among black and Latino young people. This crisis must be addressed through the city's commitment to recruit, train and open the doors of union membership to unemployed minority youths.

snippet: After its apparent demise in Congress six months ago, the Bush administration's plan to reduce air pollution from power plants returned to life on Thursday as the Environmental Protection Agency said the plan would cost less than competing proposa...
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 - After its apparent demise in Congress six months ago, the Bush administration's plan to reduce air pollution from power plants returned to life on Thursday as the Environmental Protection Agency said the plan would cost less than competing proposals.
abstract: After its apparent demise in Congress six months ago, the Bush administration's plan to reduce air pollution from power plants returned to life on Thursday as the Environmental Protection Agency said the plan would cost less than competing proposals.     The assessment came after Stephen L. Johnson, the agency administrator, presented members of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee with a detailed comparison of the administration plan, known as Clear Skies, and several others. All of the bills that were analyzed by the E.P.A. staff are intended to curb emissions of nitrogen oxides, sulfur dioxide and mercury.

snippet: The collapse of Enron seems so long ago. Much has happened in the ensuing four years, so it is easy to forget the first in a string of corporate scandals that shook our collective trust in business leaders. For an indicted executive, conditions wo...
lead_paragraph: The collapse of Enron seems so long ago. Much has happened in the ensuing four years, so it is easy to forget the first in a string of corporate scandals that shook our collective trust in business leaders. For an indicted executive, conditions would seem perfect for keeping a low profile ahead of trial.
abstract: The collapse of Enron seems so long ago. Much has happened in the ensuing four years, so it is easy to forget the first in a string of corporate scandals that shook our collective trust in business leaders. For an indicted executive, conditions would seem perfect for keeping a low profile ahead of trial.     So it was a surprise to see Kenneth Lay, the company's former chairman, claim in a recent speech that prosecutors disregarded the truth. Mr. Lay told a Houston audience that Enron was ''a strong, profitable, growing company even into the fourth quarter of 2001.'' That, of course, was the same quarter in which Enron declared bankruptcy.

headline.main: Enron Rears Its Head Again
headline.print_headline: Enron Rears Its Head Again

snippet: Rearranging Rooms On the Hard Drive    Q. The hard disk on my personal computer is partitioned into four 1.99-gigabyte drives. My C: drive frequently runs out of space, no matter what I have deleted. Will I have to erase my hard drive to consolida...
lead_paragraph: Rearranging Rooms On the Hard Drive
abstract: Rearranging Rooms On the Hard Drive    Q. The hard disk on my personal computer is partitioned into four 1.99-gigabyte drives. My C: drive frequently runs out of space, no matter what I have deleted. Will I have to erase my hard drive to consolidate the partitions?    A. Partitioning a hard drive -- dividing up its available space into smaller sections -- can help organize and manage the data stored on the computers. But like the rooms of a house, which often grow more cluttered the longer you live there, a small partition can easily fill up with digital photos, movies, music and other files that take up a lot of space.

lead_paragraph: WHILE Westchester may not be the culinary mecca of the five boroughs to the south, it has great, great soup. In fact, a small passageway off South Moger Avenue in Mount Kisco should really be renamed Soup Alley, in honor of two shops there.
abstract: WHILE Westchester may not be the culinary mecca of the five boroughs to the south, it has great, great soup. In fact, a small passageway off South Moger Avenue in Mount Kisco should really be renamed Soup Alley, in honor of two shops there.     First there is Temptation Tea House, a luxurious space with a huge rock waterfall, which sells more than a dozen Asian soups. Some are made with egg noodles, others with angel hair noodles; many are flavored with lemon grass, coconut milk or curry, and some are so spicy they could set your head aflame.

The companies making two of the programs discussed here have announced forthcoming Windows versions.

snippet: A health department inspector was attacked by a man yesterday during a visit to a day camp in the Longwood section, the police said. The inspector, a 26-year-old woman who was not identified by the authorities, arrived at the New Apple Family and ...
lead_paragraph: A health department inspector was attacked by a man yesterday during a visit to a day camp in the Longwood section, the police said. The inspector, a 26-year-old woman who was not identified by the authorities, arrived at the New Apple Family and Community Service Day Camp, a licensed camp, at 726 Prospect Avenue, about 8:30 a.m. She was admitted by Donald McKinnon, 54, who began punching, choking and biting her, the police said. The inspector fought him off, and he fled. The inspector was taken to a hospital and treated, the police said. Officers used bloodhounds to track Mr. McKinnon, who was arrested a few hours later at a nearby building. Last night, charges against him were pending, the police said. Sid Dinsay, a spokesman for the health department, said he did not know if the inspection was routine or the result of a complaint. He said day camps are inspected once a year. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

snippet: Advisory Commission to Propose New Limits On Several Popular Income Tax Deductions  President Bush's tax advisory commission indicated that it would not propose replacing the income tax with a national sales tax or a value-added tax, but would rec...
lead_paragraph: Advisory Commission to Propose New Limits On Several Popular Income Tax Deductions President Bush's tax advisory commission indicated that it would not propose replacing the income tax with a national sales tax or a value-added tax, but would recommend limits in the popular tax deductions for mortgage interest and employer-provided health insurance. [Page A1.]
abstract: Advisory Commission to Propose New Limits On Several Popular Income Tax Deductions  President Bush's tax advisory commission indicated that it would not propose replacing the income tax with a national sales tax or a value-added tax, but would recommend limits in the popular tax deductions for mortgage interest and employer-provided health insurance. [Page A1.]    New JetBlue Route Between New York and Boston  JetBlue said that it would begin offering 10 daily flights between Kennedy International Airport in New York and Boston next month, a route that has long been dominated by traditional like US Airways, Delta Airlines and Continental Airlines. [C1.]    More Questions Arise About Transactions at Refco  Questionable transactions at Refco, one of the world's biggest commodities brokerage firms, began in 1998 and continued until this year, the company said. The new disclosures raised the possibility that the company's chief executive had been inflating reported profits for years. [C1.]    Apple's iPod Sales Fall Short of Expectations  Apple Computer reported that its earnings quadrupled in the fourth quarter on strong demand for both iPods and Macs. But overall sales of iPods fell short of analysts' high expectations, causing the company's shares to plunge in after-hours trading. [C1.]    An Overseas Battle Over a Big Brand Name  A Russian company called Starbucks is in business to try to sell its name back to the other Starbucks -- the better-known company from Seattle. [C1.]    Mining Deal Would Create Biggest Nickel Producer  Inco, the Canadian mining company, said it would acquire a rival, Falconbridge, to create the world's largest nickel producer in a stock and cash deal valued at 12 billion Canadian dollars ($10.2 billion). The transaction, which will give Falconbridge shareholders 34 Canadian dollars or 0.6713 Inco shares and five Canadian cents, apparently thwarts Swiss-based Xstrata's designs on Falconbridge. Xstrata acquired just under 20 percent of the company in August and said it planned to increase its holdings. Shares of Falconbridge rose 12 percent in Toronto and 11.2 percent in New York. [C4.]    Ex-Broker Said to Be Close to Settling With S.E.C.  Theodore C. Sihpol III, a former broker with the Bank of America Corporation who was acquitted on 29 of 33 criminal charges linked to improper mutual fund trading, is close to reaching a separate settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, people briefed on the discussions said. [C3.]    Google Outlines Its Charitable Goals  Google said that it had donated $90 million to a new charitable foundation it started and would give another $175 million to nonprofit groups and what it sees as socially useful businesses over the next two to three years. [C9.]    Strong Results for Outsourcing Firms in India  India's two largest outsourcing companies, Tata Consultancy Services and Infosys Technologies, announced healthy growth in quarterly profits, indicating that Western corporations continued to vigorously outsource technology and back office operations. [C4.]    Report Warns of Nations' Misuse of Web Filtering  A new report raises questions about the use of filtering technologies -- often developed by Western companies -- by autocratic governments bent on controlling what their citizens see and do on the Web. [C8.]    Wall Street Journal to Reduce Width of U.S. Edition  The Wall Street Journal announced that it was shrinking the width of its United States edition as part of a $100 million overhaul of the newspaper. [C6.]    China Policy Divides American Business Owners  The unified support from the business community that President Bush enjoys on almost every other issue breaks down when it comes to China trade and currency. [C1.]    U.S. Trade Chief Sees Progress in Trade Talks  The United States trade chief, Rob Portman, said that he saw ''real movement'' in global trade talks, but developing countries signaled that they needed more concessions from the big powers. Mr. Portman, left, made the comments in Geneva a day after the United States and the European Union presented new proposals to cut farm tariffs and reduce agricultural subsidies in rich countries. [C4.]    Supreme Court to Consider Property Cases  The Supreme Court accepted two cases brought by property owners that challenge regulators' definition of federally protected wetlands. [A14.]    Plan to Revive a Southwestern City's Downtown  A master plan to revitalize the downtown of Las Cruces, N.M., aims to restore a Main Street that disappeared when a pedestrian mall was constructed in the 1970's, with disappointing results. Square Feet. [C10.]

snippet: Former Chief Executive of Refco Is Charged With Securities Fraud  The former chairman and chief executive of Refco, one of the world's largest commodities brokerage firms, has been charged with securities fraud, accused of hiding $435 million in t...
lead_paragraph: Former Chief Executive of Refco Is Charged With Securities Fraud The former chairman and chief executive of Refco, one of the world's largest commodities brokerage firms, has been charged with securities fraud, accused of hiding $435 million in the months before the company was taken public. The executive, Phillip R. Bennett, 57, of Gladstone, N.J., was arrested Tuesday night and charged in a criminal complaint yesterday by federal prosecutors in Manhattan. [Page C1.]
abstract: Former Chief Executive of Refco Is Charged With Securities Fraud  The former chairman and chief executive of Refco, one of the world's largest commodities brokerage firms, has been charged with securities fraud, accused of hiding $435 million in the months before the company was taken public. The executive, Phillip R. Bennett, 57, of Gladstone, N.J., was arrested Tuesday night and charged in a criminal complaint yesterday by federal prosecutors in Manhattan. [Page C1.]    Apple Unveils a Video-Playing IPod  Apple Computer introduced an iPod that can play video -- along with an online shop to fill it with television shows, short films and music videos. [C1.]    Toy Industry Moves Into Consumer Electronics  Having failed to beat the electronics industry, the toy business will join it in a big way this Christmas, offering everything from cellphones for 6-year-olds to video projectors for 8-year-olds in an effort to hold on to children who are casting aside Lego and G.I. Joe to play with their parents' gadgets. [C1.]    Google and Comcast May Seek to Buy Part of AOL  Google and Comcast are in talks with Time Warner to buy a portion of America Online, according to several people with knowledge of the negotiations. The joint bid was widely seen as a way to head off Microsoft, which has also been negotiating to buy a minority stake in AOL. [C1.]    British Court Upholds One of Pfizer's Lipitor Patents  A British court provided a mixed verdict for Pfizer on a crucial patent dispute, upholding one of the company's patents on Lipitor, its best-selling cholesterol-lowering medicine, but invalidating a second one. Shares of Pfizer, the world's biggest drug company, closed up more than 2 percent in the United States after the verdict was announced. Still, they are trading near an eight-year low, in part because of investors' concerns about a related Lipitor patent challenge in the United States, a far larger market. Market Place [C3.]    Trade Negotiators to Meet Again Next Week  Trade ministers ended three days of talks aimed at overhauling farm subsidies and import tariffs without reaching a deal, but they agreed to meet again next week. [C4.]    Automakers' Sales Are Soaring in Russia  With revenues from Russia's oil exports pulsing through the economy, car sales in the country have surged, benefiting global automakers. [C4.]    Major U.S. Stock Gauges End the Day Lower  The Dow Jones industrial average fell 36.26 points, to 10,216.91. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 7.19 points, to 1,177.68, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 23.62 points, or 1.15 percent, to 2,037.4. [C11.]    U.S. Regulators Approve Sale of Flu Vaccine  Federal drug regulators announced that they had approved for sale about 1.5 million doses of flu vaccines from Chiron, raising hopes that there will be ample vaccine supplies this flu season. [A16.]    Amtrak Board Approves Separate Unit for Northeast  The Amtrak board has approved an essential step in the Bush administration plan to break up the railroad, voting to carve out the Northeast Corridor, the tracks between Boston and Washington, as a separate division. [A14.]    Charges Are Dropped Against Former Broker  The New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, dropped criminal charges against a former broker at Bank of America, Theodore C. Sihpol III, left, whom he had accused of helping a hedge fund trade mutual funds illegally. Earlier in the day, Mr. Sihpol agreed to a $200,000 fine and a five-year ban from the securities industry to resolve related fraud charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission. He neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing. [C3.]    Northwest Seeks Approval to Void Labor Pacts  Northwest Airlines said that it had asked a bankruptcy judge for permission to void its labor contracts if its employee unions do not agree to concessions worth $1.4 billion a year. [C5.]    Ad Campaign Promotes What Is Hard to Say  Grand Marnier has introduced an advertising campaign this fall to sell its $225-a-bottle vintage liqueur, Cuvée du Cent Cinquantenaire. The fact that the name of the liqueur is hard to pronounce is part of the marketing. [C3.]    Makers of Tablet PC's Go After the Masses  Tablet PC's, with and without pens, have taken hold in some segments like education and health care, and computer makers continue to introduce models with features aimed at general consumers, professionals and management-level business users. Circuits. [C7.]

lead_paragraph: Found Again, a Manuscript in Beethoven's Own Hand A librarian at a seminary outside Philadelphia was cleaning archives last summer when she came across what may be one of the most important musicological finds in years: a working manuscript score for a piano version of Beethoven's "Grosse Fuge," a monument of classical music. The 80-page manuscript, in the composer's own hand, dates from the final months of his life. THE ARTS, PAGE E1

snippet: Usually, organizing a benefit concert is a thankless task. You start with some widely admired cause or some especially pressing need, and you add a lineup of stars who find themselves in tricky positions: at a benefit, they ignore the night's them...
lead_paragraph: Usually, organizing a benefit concert is a thankless task. You start with some widely admired cause or some especially pressing need, and you add a lineup of stars who find themselves in tricky positions: at a benefit, they ignore the night's theme at their peril. But they acknowledge it at their peril, too. Think of some of the performers at Live 8, trying valiantly to find links between African poverty and the songs in their repertory.
abstract: Usually, organizing a benefit concert is a thankless task. You start with some widely admired cause or some especially pressing need, and you add a lineup of stars who find themselves in tricky positions: at a benefit, they ignore the night's theme at their peril. But they acknowledge it at their peril, too. Think of some of the performers at Live 8, trying valiantly to find links between African poverty and the songs in their repertory.    With benefit concerts for Hurricane Katrina, things are different. The rich musical heritage of New Orleans and the Gulf Coast makes it much easier to put together a program with meaningful ties to the cause. And the stomach-churning story of the disaster and its aftermath gives musicians plenty to talk about, as KANYE WEST memorably demonstrated during NBC's telethon.    This Tuesday, some of the best-known New Orleans musicians are to appear at Madison Square Garden for a concert that's almost sure to be better than its name: ''FROM THE BIG APPLE TO THE BIG EASY.'' FATS DOMINO, who was reported missing in the flood but later rescued, is to be joined by ALLEN TOUSSAINT, THE NEVILLE BROTHERS, BUCKWHEAT ZYDECO, THE METERS, THE DIRTY DOZEN BRASS BAND, THE REBIRTH BRASS BAND and others. (Here's hoping some performers from the city's hip-hop scene -- perhaps JUVENILE or LIL' WAYNE -- will join them.) There are to be some ringers, too; it's not clear this line-up needs any help from ELTON JOHN or BETTE MIDLER or JIMMY BUFFETT, but it is scheduled to get it.  6:30 p.m., 33rd Street and Seventh Avenue, (212)307-7171 or www.thegarden.com; tickets are $50 to $500.

snippet: 10 P.M. (Food) SECRET LIFE OF... THANKSGIVING -- The holiday isn't necessarily the same all over the country. So Jim O'Connor, the host, focuses on regional Thanksgiving dishes. That means deep-fried turkey with Paul Prudhomme (above) in New Orlea...
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Food) SECRET LIFE OF... THANKSGIVING -- The holiday isn't necessarily the same all over the country. So Jim O'Connor, the host, focuses on regional Thanksgiving dishes. That means deep-fried turkey with Paul Prudhomme (above) in New Orleans (filmed about a month before Hurricane Katrina), sweet potato casserole in Atlanta, apple pie in Upstate New York and a re-creation of the original Thanksgiving feast in Plymouth, Mass. But the best part may be, as it often is in real life, the post-Thanksgiving turkey sandwich in Philadelphia.
abstract: 10 P.M. (Food) SECRET LIFE OF... THANKSGIVING -- The holiday isn't necessarily the same all over the country. So Jim O'Connor, the host, focuses on regional Thanksgiving dishes. That means deep-fried turkey with Paul Prudhomme (above) in New Orleans (filmed about a month before Hurricane Katrina), sweet potato casserole in Atlanta, apple pie in Upstate New York and a re-creation of the original Thanksgiving feast in Plymouth, Mass. But the best part may be, as it often is in real life, the post-Thanksgiving turkey sandwich in Philadelphia.    8 P.M. (Cinemax) OCEAN'S TWELVE -- (2004). The best parts of Steven Soderbergh's glamorous remake have nothing to do with the heist. It's a tie between Danny Ocean (George Clooney) fretting about whether he looks 50 and Tess Ocean (Julia Roberts) being persuaded to impersonate a movie star: JuliaRoberts. Mr. Clooney is now 44, by the way.    9 P.M. (CBS) TWO AND A HALF MEN -- It had to happen. Charlie (Charlie Sheen) and his nephew, Jake (Angus T. Jones, above right, with Mr. Sheen), fall for the same woman. She's a ballet teacher, played by Emmanuelle Vaugier of the horror movie ''SawII.'' Jake may even come to love dance class.    9 P.M. (Biography) PRIDE AND PREJUDICE -- (1995). This is the BBC and A&E version, with Colin Firth as the rich and arrogant Mr.Darcy and Jennifer Ehle (near right, with Mr. Firth) as the spirited and ahead-of-her-time Elizabeth Bennet, who absolutely cannot tolerate him. Part 1 of 3.    10 P.M. (NBC) MEDIUM -- It's always a struggle between work and home, even for psychics. Allison DuBois (Patricia Arquette) doesn't know whether to worry more about the re-election campaign of her boss, District Attorney Devalos (Miguel Sandoval), or the old college girlfriend that her husband, Joe (Jake Weber), has just run into.    MIDNIGHT (TCM) THE WOMEN -- (1939). Norma Shearer is the decent Park Avenue wife whose husband is leaving her for a déclassé sales clerk. Joan Crawford is the clerk. Rosalind Russell and Paulette Goddard have the best fight scene. George Cukor's interpretation of Clare Boothe Luce's play about wealthy women who have nothing better to do than gossip, play cards and divorce is still absolutely delicious.        ANITA GATES

snippet: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to spe...
lead_paragraph: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow.
abstract: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow.      I DON'T think that politics has paralyzed Gotham's once vaunted ability to get big things done. At this very moment, New York is driving City Water Tunnel No. 3 through bedrock 60-odd stories beneath Manhattan, one of the most colossal construction projects on earth. Nor (happily enough) did every enterprise proposed in the Good Old Days come to fruition -- like the proposal in 1893 to tear down City Hall, or Mayor William J. Gaynor's suggestion in 1910 to ram a new street through Midtown between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

snippet: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to spe...
lead_paragraph: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow.
abstract: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow.      THE inability to get large public projects off the ground in New York reflects less a lack of ambition than a failure to come to consensus over the role of government in land use. There is a tendency to criticize any public investment in projects that are not absolutely needed. We take for granted our great public works, like Central Park and the Public Library, as if they were handed down by Moses. Actually, they were created by real people with precious dollars, public and private (including some by another Moses, Robert). These are our temples.

snippet: AM I the only person who ever began the day vowing to pick up all the fallen pears from the driveway but ended up spending the afternoon in front of a computer, engrossed in an article that detailed the finer points of how and when to pick tree fr...
lead_paragraph: AM I the only person who ever began the day vowing to pick up all the fallen pears from the driveway but ended up spending the afternoon in front of a computer, engrossed in an article that detailed the finer points of how and when to pick tree fruit?
abstract: AM I the only person who ever began the day vowing to pick up all the fallen pears from the driveway but ended up spending the afternoon in front of a computer, engrossed in an article that detailed the finer points of how and when to pick tree fruit?     I can't be. At least not since the Internet organized the world's information in such a tantalizingly accessible manner that it seems remiss not to know whether pears should be allowed to ripen before picking. (No, according to a Washington State University Extension's online commentary, which warns of ''grittiness'' and ''core breakdown'' if they are left on the tree too long.)

snippet: PASCAL GRAFF, the owner and chef of Le Bouchon, has turned one of this village's lovely century-old homes into a cozy, casual French restaurant. The front porch, with its small tables, soft lighting and menu boards in classic Art Nouveau style, dr...
lead_paragraph: Cold Spring - PASCAL GRAFF, the owner and chef of Le Bouchon, has turned one of this village's lovely century-old homes into a cozy, casual French restaurant. The front porch, with its small tables, soft lighting and menu boards in classic Art Nouveau style, drew me right through the front door.
abstract: PASCAL GRAFF, the owner and chef of Le Bouchon, has turned one of this village's lovely century-old homes into a cozy, casual French restaurant. The front porch, with its small tables, soft lighting and menu boards in classic Art Nouveau style, drew me right through the front door.     Inside the three-year-old restaurant, the seduction continued. Against traditional brasserie-red walls, soft banquettes were crowded around a marble fireplace. Pussy willows filled the window sills, reflected in the mirrors.

snippet: SEVERAL stalwarts of American industry -- General Motors, Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines -- took it on the chin this week as they reckoned with years of poor decision making and some worrying global trends.    For good measure, Citigroup, the...
lead_paragraph: SEVERAL stalwarts of American industry -- General Motors, Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines -- took it on the chin this week as they reckoned with years of poor decision making and some worrying global trends.
abstract: SEVERAL stalwarts of American industry -- General Motors, Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines -- took it on the chin this week as they reckoned with years of poor decision making and some worrying global trends.    For good measure, Citigroup, the nation's biggest financial institution, reported that one of its units had become the latest company to have misplaced personal data on its customers -- 3.9 million customers, in this case -- that could be used to commit fraud.    BIG, BUT ENOUGH? -- General Motors, battling flagging sales, said it would shed 25,000 factory jobs and close some factories by the end of 2008. After the cuts, G.M. will have about 125,000 employees in North America -- 86,000 of them hourly factory workers. That is down almost 80 percent from its peak in the late 1970's, when G.M. had half of the domestic auto market. It now has 22 percent.

snippet: 8 P.M. (Food) ALL STAR THANKSGIVING -- The stars (Food Network celebrities) include Emeril Lagasse, Tyler Florence and Paula Deen (above). The recipes include honey-brined smoked turkey, French apple tart and Orange You Glad It's Thanksgiving soup...
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Food) ALL STAR THANKSGIVING -- The stars (Food Network celebrities) include Emeril Lagasse, Tyler Florence and Paula Deen (above). The recipes include honey-brined smoked turkey, French apple tart and Orange You Glad It's Thanksgiving soup.
abstract: 8 P.M. (Food) ALL STAR THANKSGIVING -- The stars (Food Network celebrities) include Emeril Lagasse, Tyler Florence and Paula Deen (above). The recipes include honey-brined smoked turkey, French apple tart and Orange You Glad It's Thanksgiving soup.    8 P.M. (TBS) THE WIZARD OF OZ -- (1939). With commercials, it may run three hours. The best special effect may be the arrival of Glinda the Good Witch of the North (Billie Burke) in a giant soap bubble. But the story still enchants, as Dorothy Gale (a glowing 17-year-old Judy Garland) of Kansas is swept away to a magical land with witches, flying monkeys and a lollipop guild. Not to mention lessons about courage, intelligence, love and the value of home. And Harold Arlen and Yip Harburg's ''Over the Rainbow.''    9 P.M. TO 1 A.M. (BBC America) MONTY PYTHON'S FLYING CIRCUS MINI-MARATHON -- These six episodes include the classic Python sketches about Spam, the Spanish Inquisition and the Ministry of Silly Walks (John Cleese, right), as well as the Royal Hospital for Overacting, the semaphore ''Wuthering Heights,'' Confuse-a-Cat and the Society for Putting Things on Top of Other Things.    9 TO 11 P.M. (NBC) MY NAME IS EARL MINI-MARATHON -- It isn't easy to do a marathon when a series has been on the air for less than two months, but this new sitcom about a blue-collar guy trying to repair his bad karma is going for it with the four most recent episodes. Tonight Earl tries to make it up to a woman he broke up with by faking his own death, teaches English as a second language to atone for having made fun of people with accents, tries to help a mother and daughter win a beauty pageant (so he can give the prize porcelain figure to his ex-wife) and sets out to help a golf fanatic put his life back together. Jaime Pressly plays Earl's ex-wife, his equal in class and good taste.    11:30 P.M. (NBC) SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE -- For viewers who skipped ''My Name Is Earl'' tonight or just can't get enough of Jason Lee, its star, Mr. Lee (left) is the ''S.N.L.'' guest host. Foo Fighters are the musical guests.     ANITA GATES

snippet: Hurricane Relief       Twenty percent of the ticket price for lunch cruises today on the Spirit of New Jersey, moored at Port Imperial Piers, Weehawken, N.J., and on Bateaux New York, at Pier 62 at Chelsea Piers, will benefit the American Red Cros...
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Relief
abstract: Hurricane Relief       Twenty percent of the ticket price for lunch cruises today on the Spirit of New Jersey, moored at Port Imperial Piers, Weehawken, N.J., and on Bateaux New York, at Pier 62 at Chelsea Piers, will benefit the American Red Cross. The cruises today are from noon to 2 p.m., and are $37 from New Jersey and $48 from Manhattan. For information on events in 17,000 restaurants around the country: dineforamerica.org.      A reception with food and entertainment will be held on Tuesday from 7 to 9 p.m. at the Cornell Club, 6 East 44th Street. Tickets are $175 each, payable by credit card or check to New Orleans Tourism Rebirth Fund. Ticket requests may be sent, with names of guests and an e-mail address for confirmation, to New Chefs Event, Venue PR, 359 Avenue of the Americas No. 2, New York, N.Y. 10014; for credit-card payments, call (212)758-5322.      A five-course New Orleans-style dinner to benefit Share Our Strength's relief fund will be held on Oct. 17 at 6:30 p.m. at the Institute of Culinary Education, 50 West 23rd Street. Tickets, $200, include a contribution of $160: (212)847-0770.    Wine, Women and Culture       A talk about women as winemakers and a tasting of wines made by women will take place tonight from 6:30 to 8 p.m. at Stony Brook Manhattan, 401 Park Avenue South (28th Street) under the auspices of the Center for Wine, Food and Culture. The cost is $55, with a second person for $45: (631)632-9404.    Downtown, a Wine Dinner       The well-stocked cellars at Bayard's, One Hanover Square (Pearl Street) in the financial district, which include the private cellar of Harry Poulakakos, an owner, will be opened for a series of monthly wine dinners. The first one, tonight, will feature California cabernet sauvignons of the 1991 vintage ($225). On Nov. 2, Burgundies from the 1996 vintage will be poured ($250). A tasting of Bryant Family wines ($595) will be held on Feb. 7. The dinners start at 6:30 p.m., after a Champagne reception at 6 p.m.: (212)514-9454 or bayards.com.    Coffee and Chocolate       A free tasting of chocolate and coffee produced according to Fair Trade standards will be held tomorrow from 12:30 to 2 p.m. at General Theological Seminary, 175 Ninth Avenue (21st Street). On Oct. 15 from 6 to 8 p.m. there will be a free talk about Fair Trade and the New York Fair Trade Coalition at the Park Slope Food Co-op, 782 Union Street (Sixth Avenue), Park Slope, Brooklyn.    Girls Club Benefit       A benefit party for the Lower East Side Girls Club, with Asian drinks and hors d'oeuvres, will be held tomorrow from 7 to 10 p.m. upstairs at Kelley & Ping, 2 East Second Street (Bowery). Admission is a donation of $25: (212)475-8600.    Full of Feijoada       An all-you-can-eat feijoada buffet will be available from noon to 4 p.m. on the last Saturday of every month through March, starting Oct. 29, at Churrascaria Tribeca, 221 West Broadway (White Street). The cost, $38, includes a caipirinha cocktail: (212)925-6969.    A Cafe's Birthday Plans       To celebrate its 20th anniversary, Union Square Cafe is organizing a series of morning events. This Saturday there will be a talk about espresso with the perfect crema from 8 to 10 a.m. at Galleria Illy, 382 West Broadway (Spring Street), $50 a person. A pumpkin-carving party for children 7 to 12 years old will be held at the restaurant, 21 East 16th Street, on Oct. 15 from 8:30 to 10 a.m., $65 a person plus two cans of food for City Harvest. Bryan Miller and Danny Meyer will talk about the food world on Oct. 18 from 8 to 10 a.m., $50. And on Oct. 19 from 8 to 10 a.m., there will be a talk about apples, a cooking demonstration and a tasting of apples and cider, $50: (212)989-3510, ext. 24.    Breaking the Fast       A break-the-fast buffet after sundown on Yom Kippur, Oct. 13, will be held at Mo Pitkin's House of Satisfaction, 34 Avenue A (2nd Street) from 7 to 10 p.m. The cost, $35 a person, includes drinks, food and music: ticketweb.com or (212)777-5660.    Sushi, Tapas and Truffles       To celebrate its 30th anniversary on Oct. 15, the Institute of Culinary Education, 50 West 23rd Street, will offer classes on sushi, tapas, chocolate truffles and wine pairings, among others, for $30 each: (212)847-0770 or iceculinary.com.    Women on Cooking       A panel discussion with some New York women who are chefs will be held on Oct. 16 at 7:30 p.m. at the 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue (92nd Street), $25: (212)415-5500 or 92Y.org.    Dining in a Blindfold       Camaje Bistro and Lounge, 85 MacDougal Street (Bleecker Street), will hold Dining in the Dark dinners on Oct. 17 at 7 p.m. and Oct. 31 at 7 p.m. and 10 p.m. Guests will be blindfolded. Tickets are $70: (212)673-8184.   FLORENCE FABRICANT

snippet: Empanada Mama, a new shop and cafe at 763 Ninth Avenue (51st Street), offers modest-sized empanadas with a choice of more than 25 fillings. There are classic pork, beef, chicken and cheese varieties, plus tuna and fried onions; spinach and cheese;...
lead_paragraph: Empanada Mama, a new shop and cafe at 763 Ninth Avenue (51st Street), offers modest-sized empanadas with a choice of more than 25 fillings. There are classic pork, beef, chicken and cheese varieties, plus tuna and fried onions; spinach and cheese; Polish kielbasa and sauerkraut; mozzarella and tomato; and even an Elvis (peanut butter and banana), as well as sweet fillings like fig, caramel and cheese. They are $1.75 to $3. The bright little shop, owned by Socrates Nanas, above, and Javier García, is the Manhattan branch of a company that has two locations in Queens. In addition to empanadas, Empanada Mama sells tamales and slushy tropical drinks, including guanabana (soursop or custard apple), lulo (green orange), pineapple, mango and passion fruit. Drinks are $4.25 each. It's open daily, 9 a.m. to midnight: (212)698-9008. FOOD STUFF

snippet: Op-Ed article by Henry Blodget says dot-com boom that began 10 years ago is viewed by some as regrettable free-for-all of idiocy and greed; says history suggests otherwise; notes that growth of Internet has paralleled that of most industries based...
lead_paragraph: TEN years ago this month, the initial public offering of the Internet pioneer Netscape set off a dot-com boom that today is usually viewed as a sort of financial kindergarten recess, a regrettable free-for-all of idiocy and greed. Although this view does capture an aspect of the period -- the arrogance and punch-drunk frivolity that come with easy money -- it misses the big picture. It also implies that had we only been smarter and more disciplined in the late 1990's, we could have spared ourselves the pain and embarrassment that followed. History suggests otherwise.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Henry Blodget says dot-com boom that began 10 years ago is viewed by some as regrettable free-for-all of idiocy and greed; says history suggests otherwise; notes that growth of Internet has paralleled that of most industries based on revolutionary technology, progressing through four phases of development: boom, bust, mature growth and decay; says today, industry has progressed to third phase, mature growth; says investors should take solace in knowing that their exuberance helps build industries, however boneheaded it may later seem; drawing (M)

snippet: WHEN ''Proof'' opens on Friday, moviegoers can count the reasons to pay attention. First, it reunites Gwyneth Paltrow with John Madden, who directed her Oscar-winning performance in ''Shakespeare in Love.'' Second, it is the first of three films o...
lead_paragraph: WHEN "Proof" opens on Friday, moviegoers can count the reasons to pay attention. First, it reunites Gwyneth Paltrow with John Madden, who directed her Oscar-winning performance in "Shakespeare in Love." Second, it is the first of three films opening this fall -- the others are "Jarhead" and "Brokeback Mountain" -- that could propel Jake Gyllenhaal to genuine, 14-carat stardom. Third, like that other Academy Award favorite, "A Beautiful Mind," "Proof" dips into the alien waters of madness and higher mathematics before settling down on the more familiar shores of family drama. And finally, it brings to the screen David Auburn's Broadway hit, which won both the Tony and the Pulitzer Prize in 2001.
abstract: WHEN ''Proof'' opens on Friday, moviegoers can count the reasons to pay attention. First, it reunites Gwyneth Paltrow with John Madden, who directed her Oscar-winning performance in ''Shakespeare in Love.'' Second, it is the first of three films opening this fall -- the others are ''Jarhead'' and ''Brokeback Mountain'' -- that could propel Jake Gyllenhaal to genuine, 14-carat stardom. Third, like that other Academy Award favorite, ''A Beautiful Mind,'' ''Proof'' dips into the alien waters of madness and higher mathematics before settling down on the more familiar shores of family drama. And finally, it brings to the screen David Auburn's Broadway hit, which won both the Tony and the Pulitzer Prize in 2001.      But in telling the story of a genius mathematician (played by Anthony Hopkins), his nakedly ambitious student (Mr. Gyllenhaal) and his possibly brilliant daughter Catherine (Ms. Paltrow), ''Proof'' also touches on the sometimes contentious issue of how and why children follow in their parents' footsteps, and of the ways in which talent is transmitted and transmuted within families.

snippet: Microsoft's chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, made a concerted effort Thursday to persuade financial analysts that the world's largest software publisher will again become a growth stock.     At Microsoft's annual briefing for analysts at its he...
lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
abstract: Microsoft's chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, made a concerted effort Thursday to persuade financial analysts that the world's largest software publisher will again become a growth stock.     At Microsoft's annual briefing for analysts at its headquarters here, Mr. Ballmer sketched a portrait of the company's endeavors centered on ''anchor businesses'' -- like its Windows operating systems for PC's and servers and its Office productivity software -- that will continue to grow ''robustly'' through the end of the decade. He also pointed to growth potential in newer areas like Microsoft's video game business and software for mobile phones, interactive television and Web searching.

snippet: Arts, Briefly column; novelists John Irving, Tom Wolfe and Jonathan Safran Foer are among about 80 writers who will participate in Library of Congress's fifth annual National Book Festival on September 24; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The Library of Congress has announced that the novelists John Irving, below, Tom Wolfe and Jonathan Safran Foer are among about 80 writers who have agreed to participate in the fifth annual National Book Festival on Sept. 24. The all-day event will have as it host Laura Bush, who organized a similar event in Texas when President Bush was governor of that state. Authors will read and discuss their works at seven themed pavilions: Fiction and Fantasy, Mysteries and Thrillers, History and Biography, Children, Teens and Children, Poetry, and Home and Family. Among the writers scheduled to give readings and sign books are the astronaut Buzz Aldrin, the presidential biographer David McCullough, E.L. Doctorow, Tom Clancy and Sandra Brown. R.W. Apple Jr., Thomas L. Friedman and David Brooks of The New York Times will also appear. Discussions and readings from the History and Biography pavilion will be broadcast live from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. on C-SPAN2, the library said. (The program will be shown again at 8 p.m.) JOHN FILES
abstract: Arts, Briefly column; novelists John Irving, Tom Wolfe and Jonathan Safran Foer are among about 80 writers who will participate in Library of Congress's fifth annual National Book Festival on September 24; photo (S)

lead_paragraph: IF you want the perfect gift for your favorite gadgeteer this holiday season, experts say it had better have a color screen, whether it is on an MP3 player, a wireless Internet device or the new sharper large-screen TV's. The big trend this year is to make entertainment devices more portable and more integrated.
abstract: IF you want the perfect gift for your favorite gadgeteer this holiday season, experts say it had better have a color screen, whether it is on an MP3 player, a wireless Internet device or the new sharper large-screen TV's. The big trend this year is to make entertainment devices more portable and more integrated.      Asked to predict what would be popular this season, technophiles -- from computer repairmen to electronics retailing chieftains -- mentioned safe bets like cameras as well as eccentric items, like a U.S.B.-powered lava light. There was one nearly universal note of agreement, and it might as well be said now: techies love the Apple iPod Nano.

snippet: Style and Substance: Quince    Q. I would like to grow a fruit tree that also has attractive flowers. Could you suggest one that would be hardy in the Hudson Valley?    A. Almost all fruit trees have attractive flowers; they simply don't have them...
lead_paragraph: Style and Substance: Quince
abstract: Style and Substance: Quince    Q. I would like to grow a fruit tree that also has attractive flowers. Could you suggest one that would be hardy in the Hudson Valley?    A. Almost all fruit trees have attractive flowers; they simply don't have them for very long. But if you are looking for a fruit that is both ornamental and productive, you cannot do better than quince, Cydonia oblonga.      Quince trees grow 12 to 15 feet tall with gnarly shapes that look wonderful against snow. The flowers, pink to white, open a bit later than apple blossoms and are framed by deep-green leaves that are fuzzy underneath.

snippet: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to spe...
lead_paragraph: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow.
abstract: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow.      EVERY two years, the Venice Architecture Biennale awards a prize for the best urban planning and architecture to a city. New York has never received this award because, apart from a handful of great old buildings, it has had little to show of architectural innovation for the past 50 years. Great architecture has rarely been a goal of our political decision makers, as we have witnessed in recent weeks.

NO project would yield more tangible benefits for our region than Moynihan Station. As a child, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, my late father, sold newspapers and shined shoes in the old Penn Station. snippet: With its library of sound samples and easy-to-use interface, the GarageBand program from Apple has been helping Macintosh mavens create and mix their own musical compositions since it was introduced early last year.      With the M-Audio iControl ...
lead_paragraph: With its library of sound samples and easy-to-use interface, the GarageBand program from Apple has been helping Macintosh mavens create and mix their own musical compositions since it was introduced early last year.
abstract: With its library of sound samples and easy-to-use interface, the GarageBand program from Apple has been helping Macintosh mavens create and mix their own musical compositions since it was introduced early last year.      With the M-Audio iControl device, people who prefer a physical recording console now have plenty of knobs to twirl in front of the screen instead of on it.     The iControl connects to the Mac through a U.S.B. port and includes buttons that correspond to many of GarageBand's onscreen controls for actions like play, stop and record. A master volume switch and a jog wheel for dialing back to a precise point in the recording are also within easy reach.

snippet: 8 P.M. (7) IT'S THE GREAT PUMPKIN, CHARLIE BROWN -- Dear, deluded Linus persuades Sally to spend Halloween night in the pumpkin patch (above), rather than trick-or-treating, in this Emmy-nominated 1966 holiday classic. Lucy bobs for apples and fin...
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (7) IT'S THE GREAT PUMPKIN, CHARLIE BROWN -- Dear, deluded Linus persuades Sally to spend Halloween night in the pumpkin patch (above), rather than trick-or-treating, in this Emmy-nominated 1966 holiday classic. Lucy bobs for apples and finds Snoopy in the water. Violet (one of the lesser-known "Peanuts" characters) decides the back of Charlie Brown's head would make a good jack-o'-lantern.
abstract: 8 P.M. (7) IT'S THE GREAT PUMPKIN, CHARLIE BROWN -- Dear, deluded Linus persuades Sally to spend Halloween night in the pumpkin patch (above), rather than trick-or-treating, in this Emmy-nominated 1966 holiday classic. Lucy bobs for apples and finds Snoopy in the water. Violet (one of the lesser-known ''Peanuts'' characters) decides the back of Charlie Brown's head would make a good jack-o'-lantern.    8 P.M. (11) GILMORE GIRLS -- There are two things very wrong on Rory Gilmore's 21st birthday. Rory (Alexis Bledel) and her mother (Lauren Graham) are barely speaking. And the birthday girl is still a college dropout. Her grandparents (Edward Herrmann and Kelly Bishop) plan an elaborate party, but are horrified to learn Rory has a sex life.    9 P.M. (VH1) I LOVE THE 80'S 3D -- In 1982, the mullet was a fashionable hairstyle, Toni Basil's ''Mickey'' was a hot video, and Trivial Pursuit was a chic way to spend an evening. At 10 p.m., the series looks at 1983, when Tom Cruise made ''Risky Business,'' Jennifer Beals (right) did ''Flashdance,'' and the most desirable holiday gifts were Cabbage Patch dolls or one of those newfangled compact discs.    9 P.M. (7) COMMANDER IN CHIEF -- So far, the administration of President Mackenzie Allen (Geena Davis) is an unlikely blend of the critical and the ridiculous. Tonight her problems include explosive-smuggling terrorists, late-night talk-show jokes about her husband (Kyle Secor) and a daughter (Jasmine Anthony) who can't go trick-ortreating anymore.    10 P.M. (13) IN THE LIFE: EVERY PICTURE TELLS A STORY -- The first newsmagazine show about gay and lesbian life begins its 14th season with Kate Clinton, its original host. Tonight's profile subjects include the Broadway legend Jerry Herman, two Greenwich Village restaurateurs and a Roman Catholic nun who for decades has spoken out against church laws forbidding homosexuality.    12:30 A.M. (13) THE LAST COWBOY -- On his isolated ranch in Porcupine, S.D., Vern Sager (left) has enemies -- cattle rustlers, international agribusiness, old age, his cows' habit of giving birth on the coldest nights of the year and the desertion of most of his family. (Pretty much all the young people in Porcupine have been lured away to the nearest big city, population 2,175.) Jon Alpert directed this ''Independent Lens'' documentary.   ANITA GATES

snippet: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to spe...
lead_paragraph: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow.
abstract: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow.      WHETHER or not one supported building the West Side stadium -- or even the city's Olympic bid, which I did -- the problems that ultimately killed the project underscore the difficulty of doing any kind of large-scale building in New York. But great cities, in the end, are defined by their ability to move past politics and local issues to create the unexpected.

NOW that the stadium is less likely to be built, one may wonder what would be the best use for the area around the Javits Convention Center (aka the Hudson Yards). All told, we are talking about 40 to 50 blocks south of Javits that extend over the rail yards and down to 28th Street. My proposal would be to use five of those blocks to expand the Javits center to 3 million square feet, from 800,000. Here's why.

lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about India's growing need for energy misstated the country's rate of consumption. It is the equivalent of 538 million tons of oil per year, not per day. A correction in this space yesterday included an erroneous reference to the rate. It represents the use of energy from all sources, including wood and charcoal, not just oil.(Go to Article)

snippet: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to spe...
lead_paragraph: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow.
abstract: HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city's 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow.      IT is much easier to defeat something in New York City than to build something. With that in mind, we should consider whether we want the easy way out or if we can accept a challenge. New Yorkers have been known for their energy, their strength and, especially in the past few years, for their courage. Maybe we're just worn out after pulling together so well after Sept. 11, 2001. It's been a haul. So maybe we just want to sit back and let things take care of themselves -- elsewhere.

snippet: HAD Hurricane Katrina not happened, or had the response to it not been so botched, it is likely that the world would have little interest in Yossi Sheffi, a professor of engineering systems at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, or in his o...
lead_paragraph: HAD Hurricane Katrina not happened, or had the response to it not been so botched, it is likely that the world would have little interest in Yossi Sheffi, a professor of engineering systems at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, or in his obscure specialty. The latter is known as "supply chain management." It is the discipline of how companies get the materials and parts they need. Until the day when something goes wrong, it seems most uninteresting. But suppose -- just suppose -- a levee breaks. Or a fire destroys a factory.
abstract: HAD Hurricane Katrina not happened, or had the response to it not been so botched, it is likely that the world would have little interest in Yossi Sheffi, a professor of engineering systems at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, or in his obscure specialty. The latter is known as ''supply chain management.'' It is the discipline of how companies get the materials and parts they need. Until the day when something goes wrong, it seems most uninteresting. But suppose -- just suppose -- a levee breaks. Or a fire destroys a factory.     The list is almost endless. I do not mean a hypothetical list. In his new book, ''The Resilient Enterprise'' (MIT Press, $29.95), Professor Sheffi seems to have unearthed every disaster to befall a modern corporation. There was the thunderstorm in Albuquerque, the port strike on the West Coast, the quake in Kobe, Japan. There was bankruptcy, terrorism and theft. There was foot-and-mouth disease, toxic chemical reaction, product tampering (Tylenol) and product failure (Firestone/Ford Explorer, and the flawed Pentium chip).

snippet: CONSUMER digital cameras have come a long way since the mid-1990's, when the Casio QV-10 (with its revolutionary liquid-crystal-display screen on the outside and 250,000-pixel pictures on the inside) hit the shelves for slightly less than $1,000. ...
lead_paragraph: CONSUMER digital cameras have come a long way since the mid-1990's, when the Casio QV-10 (with its revolutionary liquid-crystal-display screen on the outside and 250,000-pixel pictures on the inside) hit the shelves for slightly less than $1,000. Today, both picture quality and prices have gotten much better for holiday shoppers. Not only are three-megapixel cameras available for less than $100, but digital camcorders can also record right to DVD; tiny storage drives give you a reliable place to stash gigabytes of photos; and all sorts of other gadgets can be found for the person on your gift list who is obsessed with photographs or videos.

snippet: PLASTIC created the age of whimsical forms. Suddenly a radio could look like a moo cow. A chair could look like an egg. Toy ray guns could bulge and swoop. The exuberant designers of the golden age of plastic explored all the wacky, nonfunctional,...
lead_paragraph: PLASTIC created the age of whimsical forms. Suddenly a radio could look like a moo cow. A chair could look like an egg. Toy ray guns could bulge and swoop. The exuberant designers of the golden age of plastic explored all the wacky, nonfunctional, decorative shapes that household objects could take.
abstract: PLASTIC created the age of whimsical forms. Suddenly a radio could look like a moo cow. A chair could look like an egg. Toy ray guns could bulge and swoop. The exuberant designers of the golden age of plastic explored all the wacky, nonfunctional, decorative shapes that household objects could take.     Now that same plasticity is coming to microcontrollers, the computer chips that act as brains for the chirping, dancing, listening and seeing devices that line our knickknack shelves and dashboards and fill our pockets. The proliferation of cheap and cheerful programmable chips promises a new age of ''whimsical logic,'' chips that power devices whose functions are as delightfully impractical as their forms, the sort of thing you find in a stocking but keep on your desk forever.

lead_paragraph: If meat is involved, you can find me covering it in flavor-enhancing tenderizing liquids before grilling, broiling, baking or roasting it. The more you do to the meat before you cook it, the less you have to do during or after. In this case apple juice or cider gives tang and wards off stringiness, a small amount of oil keeps things juicy and maple syrup, soy, star anise, cinnamon and garlic impart deep, luscious flavor. These two meats work well in conjunction: the relatively lean chicken is enhanced in taste and texture by the pork ribs, which give off flavorsome fat as they roast. You can use whatever ribs you like; meaty ones are best, but as long as the ribs are separated, rather than in a slab, they'll do just fine. As for the chicken, I implore you to use thighs, bone-in, skin-on because the meat is more tender and the taste infinitely better. (Make sure you use a large enough roasting pan so you don't have to crowd the pan. If the pan is crowded, the meat will steam, not brown.)
